conversation.message:
Hi Company_E — thanks for the clarity. Here’s the info you requested.

30-day ramp (2–3 bullets)
1) Days 1–7: Align on goals + operating system. Confirm success metrics, owners, and timelines; build a single source of truth (tracker + RAID log); set a recurring cadence (weekly plan, mid-week check, Friday recap) and templates for written updates.
2) Days 8–21: Stabilize execution. Run stakeholder 1:1s, surface top risks/dependencies, tighten scope, and drive 2–3 priority workstreams to clear milestones; implement lightweight intake/triage so ambiguous requests get clarified, assigned, and closed.
3) Days 22–30: Scale reliability. Automate/standardize reporting, define SLAs for updates/decision-making, and hand off a repeatable playbook so the cadence continues smoothly beyond me.

Cross-functional project example (end-to-end)
- Scope: Led a cross-functional launch to roll out a new internal workflow across Sales, Ops, and Product.
- Stakeholders: Sales leadership, Ops managers, Product/Eng, and Support.
- What I did: Defined requirements + rollout plan, created the tracker/RAID log, ran weekly stakeholder syncs, wrote weekly exec updates, coordinated training/comms, and drove decision-making on open questions.
- Outcome: Shipped on the committed date; reduced turnaround time for the workflow by ~25% within the first month and cut escalations by establishing clear ownership and a consistent update cadence.

Preferred working cadence / tools
- Cadence: Daily async written update (brief: progress/risks/next), plus 1–2 structured weekly meetings (stakeholder sync + internal planning). Escalate blockers immediately rather than waiting for meetings.
- Tools: Notion/Confluence for docs, Jira/Asana for tasks, Google Sheets for trackers, Slack for async comms, and a simple RAID log for risks/issues/decisions.

If this aligns with what you need, what would be the next step (short screen, work sample, or stakeholder interview)?

conversation.message:
Hi Company_E — absolutely; here’s the 5–7 bullet outline you requested.

1) Intake SLA tiers (triage timing)
- P0 (exec-visible / customer-impacting / launch-blocking): acknowledge within 2 business hours; triage decision same day.
- P1 (material milestone risk within 1–2 weeks): acknowledge same day; triage decision within 24 business hours.
- P2 (standard requests / improvements): acknowledge within 24 business hours; triage decision within 48 business hours.

2) “Definition of ready” (info required to accept a request)
- Requestor, desired outcome/metric, due date + why that date, stakeholders/approver, dependency needs (Eng/Support/etc.), and impact if not done.
- If any of the above is missing: mark as “Needs info” and pause SLA clock until clarified (with a 1–2 question reply to unblock).

3) Intake flow / decision rights model
- Ops lead (day-to-day DRI) can approve P2/P1 reprioritization within an agreed capacity buffer (e.g., up to ~10–15% of weekly bandwidth).
- Anything that displaces an exec-visible deliverable, changes committed dates, or creates cross-team dependency risk requires explicit sign-off from the designated owner (e.g., Product/Eng lead) and/or an exec sponsor.

4) Forcing decisions on competing “top priority” asks
- Present 2–3 options with tradeoffs (timeline/quality/scope) + explicit “what slips” list.
- Make a clear recommendation based on impact and reversibility (and who bears the cost), then request a single approver to choose by a specific deadline.

5) Escalation triggers (concrete)
- Any exec-visible milestone at risk of slipping >2 business days.
- Cross-team dependency blocked >2 business days (or no named owner / no ETA).
- Two stakeholders both claiming P0/P1 with conflicting timelines and no single decision-maker identified within 24 hours.
- Scope increase >15% without timeline/resource adjustment.
- Repeated intake without “definition of ready” info from the same stakeholder (pattern causing churn).

6) What my escalation note contains (tight + decision-oriented)
- TL;DR + decision needed by when; current status; impact/risk; options/tradeoffs; my recommendation; owners + next steps; explicit ask (approve option A/B/C).

7) Dependency tracking representation
- Each work item has: dependency type (needs/blocked-by), owning team + named owner, ETA/date needed, risk level, and “last touched” date; anything blocked auto-surfaces in the weekly update and triggers escalation per thresholds above.

Also, I’ll check spam/promotions for the calendar invite/video link; if I don’t see it shortly, I’ll reply with an alternate email for a resend.

Looking forward to Wed 10:00–10:25am ET.

1) Week-by-week outcomes (definition of “done”)

  • Confirm decision-rights / approvers and publish a v1 intake “definition of ready” + SLA tiers (P0/P1/P2).

  • Dependency ownership clarified for top items (named owners + ETAs) and an escalation log started.

  • Weekly exec update fully templated and running with consistent metrics (RAG status, top risks, decisions needed).
  • Intake SLAs measurably met for P0/P1 (tracked), with a visible backlog and aging.
  • RAID reviewed 1–2x/week; blocked dependencies surfaced early with decision-ready escalation notes.
  • Light playbook draft + training session for stakeholders on “how to request work / how priorities get set.”

- End of Week 6 (Handoff-ready system):
  • Finalized playbook + handoff: roles/DRIs, SLAs, templates, escalation thresholds, and maintenance checklist.
  • Clean backlog with categorization (do now / schedule / defer) and documented tradeoffs.

2) Artifacts I’ll leave behind

- RAID: risks/issues/decisions log with escalation thresholds and “decision needed by” field.
